channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Wildfires Rage, Californians Fear the Coronavirus at Shelters
item.description: Evacuees along the rural Central Coast have fled wildfires, but more populated areas bring more risk from the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:description: Cenaida Perez and her 3-year-old daughter, Adriana, at an evacuation center in Vacaville, Calif. They were forced out of their home because of a mandatory wildfire evacuation.

item.title: Immigrant ‘Dreamers’ in Search of a Job Are Being Turned Away
item.description: President Trump hopes to end DACA, which has granted employment authorization to thousands of young immigrants. Already, some large employers are refusing to hire them.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Maria Alejandra Cardona for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Rodriguez, a DACA recipient from Venezuela, received a rejection letter from one company after revealing his immigration status.

item.title: School Nurses Are on the Coronavirus Front Lines. But Many Schools Don’t Have One.
item.description: Less than 40 percent of the nation’s schools had a full-time nurse before the pandemic, and there has been no national effort to hire more.
item.dc:creator: Dan Levin
item.media:description: New York City hired more nurses after the city’s powerful teachers’ union said its members should not return to classrooms without a nurse in each school building.

item.title: Most of $600 Million Settlement in Flint Water Crisis Will Go to Children
item.description: The settlement still needs federal court approval, but Flint residents were being cautiously optimistic after the drawn-out crisis: “I just want it to be over.”
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Gray
item.media:credit: Erin Kirkland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers distributing water bottles in Flint, Mich., on Thursday. Many people who live in Flint continue to rely on bottled water for drinking and cooking.

item.title: Highlights From the Democratic National Convention: Night 4
item.description: On the last night of the convention, Joseph R. Biden Jr. officially accepted the Democratic nomination for president. In the most important speech of his career, he said that Americans “will overcome this season of darkness.”
item.dc:creator: Nilo Tabrizy and Dmitriy Khavin
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. pitched himself as a sober, seasoned leader who stood the best chance of defeating President Trump.

item.title: Joe Biden Accepts Presidential Nomination: Full Transcript
item.description: In his acceptance speech on the final night of the Democratic National Convention, Mr. Biden vowed to help lead the nation through a ‘season of darkness’ and restore decency to America.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. accepted the Democratic presidential nomination on Thursday in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: Washington Police Officer Charged With Murdering Man Outside Grocery Store
item.description: Officer Jeffrey Nelson of the Auburn Police Department was charged under a new state law that makes it easier to hold the police accountable for the unjustified use of deadly force, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: Closing Night at the D.N.C.: Joe Biden Accepts Democratic Nomination
item.description: Mr. Biden urged Americans to have faith that they could “overcome this season of darkness,” and he pledged to bridge the country’s divisions in ways President Trump had not.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. pitched himself as a sober, seasoned leader who stood the best chance of defeating President Trump.

item.title: DNC Highlights: Speeches from Joe Biden, Michael Bloomberg, and More
item.description: For days, Democrats at the convention cast Joe Biden as a big-tent candidate for a big-tent moment. On Thursday, he made a broad appeal for support.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. pitched himself as a sober, seasoned leader who stood the best chance of defeating President Trump.

item.title: Here’s What to Watch as the Postmaster General Testifies Before Congress
item.description: Louis DeJoy’s appearance before the Senate Homeland Security Committee will be his first congressional testimony since he suspended cost-cutting measures at the Postal Service.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane, Hailey Fuchs and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
item.media:credit: Bill Clark/CQ-Roll Call, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Friday’s hearing before a Republican-controlled Senate committee is expected to be far friendlier to Louis DeJoy, center, than a House hearing on Monday.

item.title: Trump will hold a funeral service for his brother at the White House on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Robert S. Trump embraced his brother after the president-elect delivered his victory speech on election night in 2016.

item.title: Stephen and Ayesha Curry Will Endorse Biden at Tonight's DNC
item.description: The N.B.A. star has long been a critic of President Trump’s, but he had previously expressed reluctance to involve himself in a presidential campaign.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb

item.title: In his speech, Joe Biden will preview a fall campaign strategy against Trump.
item.description: Mr. Biden plans to ride out of the convention with a general election message centered on compassion, linking his biography of setback and recovery to the lives of Americans experiencing hardships.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: People watched the Democratic National Convention at an outdoor viewing party in Boston on Wednesday. Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his running mate, Senator Kamala Harris, will campaign mostly virtually after the convention ends.

item.title: At DNC, Biden Previews a Fall Campaign of Contrasts With Trump
item.description: Mr. Biden rides out of the D.N.C. with a general election message centered on compassion, linking his biography of setback and recovery to the lives of Americans experiencing hardships.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Aides to Joseph R. Biden Jr. hope to capitalize on all the focus on President Trump during the Republican National Convention next week by sharpening their criticism.

item.title: Instead of Isolating Iran, U.S. Finds Itself on the Outside Over Nuclear Deal
item.description: Allies and adversaries alike have refused to recognize the Trump administration’s demand for sanctions, potentially weakening American authority worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo called for the restoration of sanctions against Iran during a trip to the United Nations headquarters in New York on Thursday.

item.title: Joe Biden Finally Got the Timing Right
item.description: More than three decades after his first presidential run, in the midst of a deadly pandemic and without his son Beau at his side, the former vice president has met his moment.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. accepted the Democratic presidential nomination on Thursday after three campaigns, eight years as vice president and 36 years in the Senate.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Flu shots are key to warding off a ‘twindemic' — a resurgence of the coronavirus paired with a severe flu season.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Kamala Harris’s Father, Donald Harris, is a Prominent Economist
item.description: Donald J. Harris, a Jamaican-born economics professor, has expressed regret that a custody battle brought his close contact with his daughters “to an abrupt halt.”
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Kamala Harris campaign, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Donald Harris holding his daughter Kamala in April 1965.

item.title: Arrest Disrupts Bannon’s Efforts to Stay Relevant After Leaving White House
item.description: Since leaving the Trump administration, the former senior adviser was caught up in federal investigations and lost command of the far-right arena he once ruled.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman, Michael S. Schmidt and Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon leaving Federal District Court in Manhattan on Thursday. He was arrested on charges of defrauding donors to a campaign to privately fund a border wall.

item.title: Trump Goes on Offensive, Starting With an Attack on Harris
item.description: President Trump sought to stoke fear of immigrants by offering a brutal description of a case involving an undocumented immigrant who was included in a jobs program while Kamala Harris was the top prosecutor in San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Linda Qiu
item.media:description: President Trump unleashed a barrage of attacks against his Democratic opponents on Thursday during a campaign event in Old Forge, Pa.

item.title: Biden’s Balancing Act
item.description: Can he please the left without angering the center, and vice versa?
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Kansas City Chiefs Ban Headdresses and Native American-Themed Face Paint at Stadium
item.description: The announcement came just over a month after Washington’s football team announced, under pressure from corporate sponsors, that it would drop its logo and the Redskins name.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Chiefs fans before a game against the Los Angeles Chargers in 2018.

item.title: Christine Jahnke, Speech Coach for Women in Politics, Dies at 57
item.description: A backstage fixture at Democratic conventions, she helped speakers work with the teleprompter, read the audience and sharpen their message.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye

item.title: Poor Planning Left California Short of Electricity in a Heat Wave
item.description: Scores of power plants were down or operating below their capacity just as hot weather drove up demand.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:description: The Ivanpah solar plant, in the Mojave Desert, was among the California power plants listed as operating below capacity last week.

item.title: What To Know About Joe Biden's DNC Speech Tonight
item.description: The last three nights have built steadily toward the unveiling of Mr. Biden as a president-in-waiting. Now is the time for him to step into the role he’s been wanting for more than 30 years.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. will accept the Democratic presidential nomination on Thursday.

item.title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus Will Cap a Week of Starring Roles for 4 Actresses at DNC
item.description: Ms. Louis-Dreyfus was the final television star to guide viewers through the Democratic National Convention, after Kerry Washington, Tracee Ellis Ross and Eva Longoria.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: Kerry Washington hosted the third night of the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday.

item.title: The Republican embrace of QAnon goes far beyond Trump.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: A small but growing number of Republicans are donning the QAnon mantle, transforming the wild conspiracy theory into an offline political movement.

item.title: Barack Obama and Kamala Harris attracted the convention’s biggest TV audience yet.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris with Joseph R. Biden, Jr. are seen on a screen at an outdoor viewing party of the Democratic National convention in Massachusetts.

item.title: The Republican Embrace of QAnon Goes Far Beyond Trump
item.description: As the president all but endorses the internet-driven conspiracy theory, it is shifting from the fringes of the internet to become an offline political movement.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A QAnon rally near the White House in September 2019.

item.title: Fact check: Trump criticized a criminal justice initiative started by Harris and distorted Biden’s positions.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris with Joseph R. Biden, Jr. on Wednesday.

item.title: Salmonella Outbreak Linked to Bagged Peaches Sickens Dozens
item.description: At least 68 cases and 14 hospitalizations have been reported in nine states, federal health authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León

item.title: From Obama, An Unusually Emotional Display at the Democratic Convention
item.description: Barack Obama’s excoriation of his successor and his plea to voters who he says will decide the fate of American democracy was an unusually emotional performance for the former president.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker

item.title: Beth Salamensky, Lawyer Who Found an L.G.B.T.Q. Community, Dies at 43
item.description: She moved from the Chicago area to Los Angeles, where she joined a lesbian and gay synagogue. But after falling destitute, she withdrew and died of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Julia Carmel
item.category: Beth Chayim Chadashim (Los Angeles, Calif, Synagogue)

item.title: Near Biden’s Pennsylvania hometown, Trump calls him ‘a puppet of the radical left movement.’
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: President Trump with supporters upon his arrival in Pennsylvania.

item.title: Mitch McConnell’s opponent answers his debate challenge with another.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Greg Eans/The Messenger-Inquirer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Amy McGrath, a Democrat running for Senate in Kentucky, is hoping to unseat Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader.

item.title: Oleandrin, Covid-19 Treatment Pitched to Trump, Could Be Dangerous
item.description: The chief executive of My Pillow, a Trump donor, claims oleandrin is a miracle cure for Covid-19. But no studies have shown that it is safe or effective, and the shrub it’s derived from is poisonous.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: The extract is derived from Nerium oleander, a flowering shrub native to the Mediterranean.

item.title: Trump Appears in Pennsylvania, Biden's Home State, Igniting a Turf War
item.description: In a visit to Pennsylvania hours before Joe Biden’s nomination speech, President Trump sought to undermine the former vice president’s Scranton roots, saying he had “abandoned” the state.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited his childhood neighborhood in Scranton, Pa., last month.

item.title: Former Postal Governor Tells Congress Mnuchin Politicized Postal Service
item.description: David C. Williams also said he raised concerns about Louis DeJoy, the embattled postmaster general, before he was hired.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos, Alan Rappeport, Kenneth P. Vogel and Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: David C. Williams, the former vice chairman of the Postal Service's board of governors, issued a blistering assessment of the service’s new leader.

item.title: Top G.O.P. national security officials call Trump ‘unfit to lead’ and back Biden.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Among the signatories are former officials such as John Negroponte, left, the former director of national intelligence, and General Michael Hayden.

item.title: U.S. Mail Delays Slow Delivery of Medicines
item.description: In addition to concerns over mail-in voting, the cost-cutting at the Postal Service affects the millions of people who get their prescriptions by mail.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.media:description: A U.S. Postal Service mail carrier in Portland, Maine, this week.
